recent_reviews.title: Black Bag
recent_reviews.review:
Just enough cinematic and directorial flair to make up for the run-of-the-mill spy plot.

Top wins
- 93 minute runtime
- Marisa Abela
- Black Bag becoming a part of my everyday conversations with my wife ("did you eat all of the leftovers we were saving for lunch?" "sorry sweetie, black bag")

recent_reviews.title: Heretic
recent_reviews.review: The curse of the underwhelming third act horror movie continues! Why is it so hard to stick the landing with this genre?

If I start talking to Sarah the way Peter talks to Ellie what do you think would happen?

Also,

This review may contain spoilers.

Ex Machina and Bodies Bodies Bodies had a baby

recent_reviews.title: Mickey 17
recent_reviews.review:
First off, my utter adoration for Robert Pattinson is reaffirmed (not that it needed any reaffirmation), but that is where my positive commentary ends.

This had me hooked at first with its campy tone and interesting, heady ideas (the many yous you are), but then it didn't follow through on anything, got strange and flat-feeling and lost me completely. It was still entertaining throughout so I'll give it three bags of popcorn.

I also don't need any more Trump-ed up caricatures in the movies I watch - I get enough of that from the news.

Also also the creepers were totally Ohmus

recent_reviews.title: I'm Still Here
recent_reviews.review:
No shade to my girl Mikey, but how tf did Fernanda not win...

MILD SPOILER BELOW

A fire alarm went off in our theater the exact moment that Rubens was being taken away by the police and it interrupted a critical vibe shift.

When we got back in our seats 30 minutes later the restart was abrupt and felt disjointed from the idyllic exposition of the first third of the movie.

recent_reviews.title: A Different Man
recent_reviews.review:
So meta it hurts, so cringe-inducing it kills, and darkly hilarious!

The trailer gives the entire arc of the movie away but I still had fun. Anyway, fuck trailers.

LITTLE SPOILER BELOW

Fun fact: this is the second movie in the past few months I've made Danny (who hates being grossed out) watch that involves someone graphically ripping apart their face or body

recent_reviews.title: Station Eleven
recent_reviews.author: Emily St. John Mandel
recent_reviews.review:
Re-reading this post-pandy hits a lot harder. The chapters that describe the fallout from the flu went from being interesting sci-fi to fridge-horror what-ifs about the real pandemic.

Such a solid work of literary-ish sci-fi. I could see someone criticizing this book for having an anti-climatic ending, but they would have missed the the fact that it was all about the journey.

ORIGINAL 2017 REVIEW BELOW

I'll always love a well executed, deeply intertwined, mosaic piece.

Read this very shortly after reading The Road, and the astounding differences in tone were fun to think about.

recent_reviews.title: The Seven Moons of Maali Almeida
recent_reviews.author: Shehan Karunatilaka
recent_reviews.review:
This was a creative, kafkaesque take on the bardo, and naturally it reminded me of my favorite George Saunder's novel, but MAN I did not connect with the writing style. The second person threw me, I found it tonally confused, and my god the acronyms just wouldn't stop.

On the plus side I learned a lot about Sri Lanka and TAMIL came up in a nyt crossword while I was reading it so there's that I guess.

recent_reviews.title: Playground
recent_reviews.author: Richard Powers
recent_reviews.review:
Absolutely wonderful. I liked this significantly better than The Overstory and I already liked that one a lot. It took a little to get going, but once the characters and story were established it started to hum. Like his other books, this has themes of environmentalism, technology, friendship, love, and family. For a lot of other novels that would feel like too much, but Powers is so good at weaving themes and meanings into the narrative that it never felt like this was overreaching.

I am a big fan of meta-review about "cinematic moments" I had sitting in movies theaters and "literary moments" I had reading something wherever I was reading it. Well, this gave me a big one as I stayed up to finish it alone in a ski lease in Tahoe. I am putting it up there with a few other notable moments like:
- Finishing 100 Years on a boat with my family
- Reading book 7 of HP for the first time curled up in my childhood bedroom
- The end of And the Mountains Echoed on a ferry to Martha's Vineyard

recent_reviews.title: Onyx Storm (The Empyrean, #3)
recent_reviews.author: Rebecca Yarros
recent_reviews.review:
I think if I tried to list out all my complaints they would be as long as the book itself. But I will try to list a few!
- so many fucking names
- absolutely ZERO character development
- bizarre pacing, esp during scenes that should have been intense, everything just felt... flat
- filler plot that accomplishes just about nothing
- infuriatingly repetitive conversations between main characters

The only reason this gets 2 stars and not 1 is the hangover effect from the first book. I still like the world that was built and am desperate for more crumbs of information about it.

Where were you when the era of dragon smut died?

recent_reviews.title: Manacled
recent_reviews.author: SenLinYu
recent_reviews.review:
Yes that's right I started 2025 off by reading smutting HP fanfic

This was OK, it had a good premise but started dragging in pace about halfway through and never recovered

recent_reviews.title: Orbital
recent_reviews.author: Samantha Harvey
recent_reviews.review: I can understand someone not liking this book, but I did enjoyed its poetic, non-fictionish style. The plot is barely existent but the writing and multicultural space-musings kept me engaged throughout

recent_reviews.title: We Have Always Lived in the Castle
recent_reviews.author: Shirley Jackson
recent_reviews.review: I did not like this very much - but it broke my multi month reading dry spell so it has that going for it

recent_reviews.review: My favorite parts were the parts about the planets
